journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Predicting the pedestrian pre-impact speed from the pedestrian projection distance and vehicle damage measurements

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland

author-notes.corresp: Mathew Lyons, Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Trinity College, Parsons Building, College Green, Dublin 2, Ireland. Email: lyonsm2@tcd.ie

abstract.p: Methods to estimate the pre-impact pedestrian speed from limited post-accident measurements are required both for biomechanics research and for legal applications following vehicle–pedestrian collisions, but none is currently available. Such a method is presented in this paper. A constant-inertial-property pedestrian model based on the conservation of momentum is first shown to predict satisfactorily the transverse offset of a pedestrian between the primary and secondary impacts in wrap-trajectory vehicle–pedestrian collisions and is then used in a Monte Carlo environment to predict the pedestrian pre-impact speed distribution utilizing an estimate of the vehicle speed based on the pedestrian projection distance, the ratio of the longitudinal offset to the transverse offset for the pedestrian primary and secondary contact locations on the vehicle (indicated by the primary and secondary vehicle damage locations) and, where available, information on the pedestrian gait stance at impact (derived from the injury location on the head). Separate analysis of recently published Fourier relationships between the transverse offset and the contact location on the head derived from modelling with Mathematical Dynamic Models (MADYMO) software is used to show that the gait stance is related to the location on the head of head injuries from the vehicle contact, and that contact locations significantly anterior or posterior of the coronal plane are predominant. Results from the constant-inertial-property pedestrian model show that significant differences occur between the ratio of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset with the struck leg leading and the corresponding ratio with the struck leg lagging. The special case of nominally zero transverse offset between the primary and secondary damage locations from the contacts of the pedestrian with the vehicle is considered, and pedestrian speed confidence limits for accident reconstruction purposes are provided. Regression equations relating the pedestrian speed to the pedestrian projection distance and the ratio of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset of the damage location on the vehicle are presented. These provide the first means to predict the pedestrian speed from limited post-accident damage locations on the vehicle and the pedestrian projection distance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The World Health Organization has estimated that 1.2 × 106 people die in road traffic accidents every year,1 and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has reported that pedestrians are a significant proportion of these.2 Reducing the effects of pedestrian collisions requires a clear understanding of the collision events. Given the limited feasibility of staged testing in pedestrian collisions, detailed computational modelling (see, for example, the papers by Serre et al.,3 Simms and Wood4 and Van Rooij et al.5) is important for understanding injury causation. However, this approach requires significant information about the pre-impact configuration.6,7 Therefore, methods to estimate the pre-impact configuration from limited post-accident measurements are required both for biomechanics research and for legal applications.

The vehicle speed is often estimated using the pedestrian projection distance (see, for example, the papers by Wood and co-workers8–11). However, there are no methods for estimating the pedestrian pre-impact speed, and this is the focus of the current paper. The pedestrian speed influences the head impact location on the vehicle12 which, owing to stiffness variations, influences the injury outcome.7,13 It may also affect the outcome of legal proceedings which frequently follow an accident case.

The vehicle and pedestrian speeds and the pedestrian gait stance at impact cannot generally be measured directly post-accident, and often the only objective evidence available is the pedestrian projection distance, vehicle damage locations and pedestrian injury patterns. As stated, the pedestrian projection distance can be used to estimate the vehicle speed. For the pedestrian speed, it has been hypothesized that the transverse offset between the primary and secondary damage locations on the vehicle of a pedestrian struck on the side (Figure 1) could be used for pedestrian speed estimation.12,14 The longitudinal offset between the primary and secondary damage locations on the vehicle (L) is the horizontal distance from the bumper contact location to the head contact location (see Figure 1). If the primary damage location is on the bonnet leading-edge, the bumper contact location is taken as the point on the bumper directly ahead of the bonnet leading-edge damage. For the transverse offset H, this is the offset between the two measureable damage locations on the vehicle. If the primary damage location is on the bonnet leading-edge, then this is used even though the first contact would have been at the bumper. The transverse offset is significantly influenced by the vehicle speed and whether the struck leg is forward or rearward of the midline of the body at impact,13 and estimates for these would therefore also be required for this reconstructive approach to be feasible. The pedestrian gait stance also influences the part of the head which strikes the vehicle, i.e. anterior or posterior to the coronal plane (Figure 2), where the angle θ is the amount of head rotation for a side-struck pedestrian between the primary contact with the vehicle (by the thighs and the pelvis) and the subsequent secondary head contact with the vehicle.

caption.p: Longitudinal offset L and transverse offset H for the primary and secondary pedestrian impact locations with the vehicle.
Schematic diagram demonstrating the rotation θ of the head between the primary and secondary contacts of the pedestrian impact on the vehicle.

sec.p: The multi-body pedestrian model obtained with Mathematical Dynamic Models (MADYMO) software15 is often used to perform an analysis of pedestrian kinematics (see, for example, the papers by van Hoof et al.16 and Elliott et al.17), and recent MADYMO work has shown that, using the gait cycle descriptions given by Untariou et al.,18 anterior head contact (with respect to the coronal plane) is associated with the 0–15% and 70–100% portions of the gait cycle (corresponding to the struck leg lagging), and posterior head impact (with respect to the coronal plane) is associated with the 15–70% portions of the gait cycle (corresponding to the struck leg leading).13 Thus the location of injuries on the head (anterior or posterior) may be used to provide an indication of the gait stance at impact for a pedestrian struck from the side. It has also recently been found that a transverse offset of zero often occurs for a non-stationary pedestrian.14 However, that analysis was confined to a single vehicle type and a single pedestrian anthropometric.19

It is evident therefore that there are complex relations between the vehicle speed, the pedestrian speed, the pedestrian gait stance and the transverse offset, and that these may be further influenced by variations in the pedestrian anthropometrics and the vehicle type. It is hypothesized here that the ratio of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset may prove to be a robust surrogate for the ratio of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle pre-impact speed, and that this ratio remains effectively constant for broad ranges of pedestrian anthropometrics and vehicle sizes.

However, real-world collisions involve ranges of pedestrian anthropometrics and vehicle types, and predictive tools for accident reconstruction need to account for this. Statistical uncertainty can be well represented using Monte Carlo simulation methods (see, for example, the papers by Wood and co-workers8,10) , but a computationally efficient and stable pedestrian model is a prerequisite for this. Accordingly, in this paper a previously validated constant-inertial-property (CIP) momentum-based pedestrian model is further validated for predicting the pedestrian transverse offset and is then applied in a Monte Carlo simulation environment to assess the feasibility of using the transverse offset of the damage patterns on the vehicle and the injury region on the head of a struck pedestrian, together with the pedestrian projection distance, as a means to predict the pedestrian pre-impact speed.
The objectives of this paper are as follows:

list-item.p: to demonstrate that the CIP model can satisfactorily predict the transverse offset in wrap-trajectory vehicle–pedestrian collisions where the pedestrian struck was from the side;

to analyse further the dependence of the head’s longitudinal rotation between primary and secondary impacts and the vehicle impact speed through analysis of recently reported Fourier relationships derived from modelling with MADYMO;13
to investigate the distribution of pedestrian speeds for the case of a nominally zero transverse offset;

to use the CIP model in a Monte Carlo environment to predict the pedestrian pre-impact speed using an estimate of the vehicle speed based on the pedestrian projection distance, the ratio of the longitudinal and transverse offsets of the pedestrian primary and secondary contact locations on the vehicle (indicated in practice by the damage locations) and the pedestrian gait stance at impact (derived, where available, from the injury location on the head);
to provide pedestrian speed prediction confidence limits for accident reconstruction purposes.

sec.title: Methods
CIP model
sec.p: The CIP pedestrian model12 is a three-dimensional expansion of Wood’s planar single-segment model (SSM).20 The formulations for both are based on the conservation of linear and angular momentum of the vehicle–pedestrian system. The pedestrian is modelled as a single rigid body. The principal additional assumption of the CIP model is that the stance and moments of inertia of the pedestrian remain constant. Any stance can be modelled parametrically. The input parameters required are therefore the mass and contact points for the vehicle, together with the mass, inertia and gait stance for the pedestrian. The contact stiffness is not required as impacts are assumed to be plastic, and rigid body relations are enforced. The SSM was previously validated for forward and wrap projections in terms of the projection distance as a function of the vehicle impact speed, time to head impact, head impact velocity and head contact location8,10,20–22 by comparison with over 100 staged tests and over 200 real collisions. The CIP model has additionally been shown to reproduce the head trajectory in the plane defined by the forward and vertical directions of the vehicle travel in comparison with staged cadaver tests at 40 km/h, and the longitudinal offset L and the transverse offset H between the primary and secondary body contact/impact locations on the vehicle by comparison with staged cadaver tests, dummy tests and accident reconstructions.12 It has also been shown to predict the pedestrian wrap-around ratio over a broad range of vehicle impact speeds.23

sec.title: CIP model further validation for transverse offset
sec.p: To the present authors’ knowledge, there have beene no staged tests with moving cadavers to represent walking or running pedestrians. However, staged tests with dummies have been carried out in Germany by the Crash Test Service (CTS). In particular, a series of six tests were carried out25–30 with dummies travelling transversely across the fronts of cars at pedestrian speeds Vp of 6–11 km/h that were struck at car speeds Vc of 33–55 km/h. The H/L values ranged from 0.13 to 0.32 while the Vp/Vc values ranged from 0.12 to 0.33. In five of the six tests the car was unbraked, while in the braked test there was no dive.

To test further the ability of the CIP model to predict the pedestrian transverse offset for the case of a pedestrian struck from the side by a moving vehicle, a comparison was made with the response predictions of the recently validated MADYMO 50th percentile male pedestrian model15,17 over ranges of vehicle and pedestrian speeds. The vehicle geometry was adapted from that used by Subit et al.24 and the contact characteristics were taken from the work of Simms and Wood.4 No braking was implemented. The simulation matrix consisted of three vehicle speeds (5 m/s, 10 m/s and 15 m/s) and three pedestrian speeds (0 m/s, 1.4 m/s and 2.8 m/s). For the modelling with MADYMO, the gait cycle was simulated using the method proposed by Untariou et al.,18 where the start of the gait cycle (0%) corresponds to the right-heel strike. The cycle can be broadly divided into two regions, 0–15% and 70–100%, corresponding to the struck leg lagging and 15–70% corresponding to the struck leg leading. Subdividing the gait cycle into 10% increments for modelling purposes resulted in a total of 90 MADYMO simulations. The mean and the range over the gait cycle of the transverse offset between the primary and secondary contact locations on the vehicle for the MADYMO and CIP modelling cases were compared.

sec.title: Application of the CIP model to the relationships between Vp, Vc, H and L
sec.p: A Monte Carlo CIP model data set (data set 1) was generated (N = 1,000,000) for pedestrians struck from the side by a moving vehicle to account for uncertainty in the input parameters (the gait, vehicle shape, pedestrian size, pedestrian speed and vehicle speed). The ranges of input parameters are given in Table 1. The broad range of input pedestrian speeds was chosen to cover all practical cases. The model outputs are the transverse offset H and the longitudinal offset L between the primary and secondary contacts of the pedestrian with the vehicle (see Figure 1).

caption.p: Input parameters for the Monte Carlo CIP model (data set 1).

tr.td: Ford Focus (2004), Ford Fiesta (2008), Toyota Avensis (2009), Toyota Corolla (2007), Volkswagen Golf (2009), Volkswagen Passat (2005), Renault Clio (2005), Renault Megane (2008)
Normal (mean stature, 1.68 m; standard stature, 0.18 m; mean mass, 69 kg; standard mass, 25.3 kg)
−30 km/h to +30 km/h with a limit of Vp = 2Vc

sec.p: Using the H, L, Vp and Vc data from the CIP model, linear regression equations relating Vp/Vc to H/L were generated (Appendix 1) for overall, normal and probable confidence limits as well as for deciles (10–90%). During accident reconstruction, the measured H and L values can thus be converted to the ratio of the pedestrian speed to the car speed using these regression relations. Using either a known car speed or a car speed estimated from the pedestrian projection distance,8 a value for the pedestrian speed can be obtained.

sec.title: Case when H/L is nominally zero
sec.p: To investigate the pedestrian and vehicle speeds when H/L is close to or equal to zero, the distribution of Vp/Vc values was examined for cases when H/L is between −0.025 and 0.025 (for both the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case and also for the general case where the gait stance is not known). The range for H/L from −0.025 to 0.025 was chosen as the uncertainty in the measurement of H was estimated to be about 2.5 cm, and for a nominal L value of 1 m this gives a ratio for H/L of 0.025. The distribution of the ratios Vp/Vc of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle speed in these cases was determined.

sec.title: Determining the pedestrian gait from the head injury pattern
sec.p: Previous MADYMO-based analysis revealed third-order Fourier relationships between the pedestrian gait and the angle of head rotation θ (see Figure 2).13 A head rotation of 0° means no rotation, i.e. the side of the pedestrian’s head struck the car (see Figure 2). To investigate the likelihood of being able to predict from the location on the head of head injury whether the struck leg was leading or lagging, analysis of the Fourier relationships in the paper by Elliott et al.13 was performed. A second Monte Carlo data set (data set 2) was produced (N = 1,000,000) using these Fourier relationships (Table 2). Since the Fourier coefficients are inversely related to the vehicle impact speed, by selecting random vehicle speeds and random positions in the gait cycle, a distribution of head rotations relative to the coronal plane was generated as a function of the vehicle speed. This Monte Carlo simulation used one pedestrian type, one pedestrian speed, one car type, the full gait cycle and vehicle speeds between 5 m/s and 30 m/s.

caption.p: Input parameters for Monte Carlo head angle simulation.

sec.title: Relationship between the vehicle speed and the pedestrian projection distance
sec.p: The strong relationship between the pedestrian projection distance and the vehicle impact speed is well established;7,10 Wood and co-workers8–10 developed a model for wrap-projection cases, and a Monte Carlo approach showed that the model predicted both the mean and the uncertainty in the relationship between the projection distance and the vehicle speed by comparison with staged dummy and cadaver tests. On the basis of this, regressions for six different confidence limits (0.01%, 5%, 25%, 75%, 95% and 99.8%) for the vehicle speed as a function of the projection distance were presented.8 Analysis of these shows that the distribution of predicted speeds can be considered to be broadly normal over a large range of projection distances (0–45 m). Figure 3 shows that the standard deviation of the vehicle speed predicted using the 25th percentile and 75th percentile limits is very similar to the standard deviation predicted using the 2.5th percentile and 95th percentile limits and the 0.01st percentile and 99.8th percentile limits respectively (see the section on the approaches for pedestrian speed prediction in accident reconstruction for definitions of these terms). Accordingly, Monte Carlo modelling can be used to generate a normal distribution of vehicle impact speeds for a given pedestrian projection distance.

caption.p: Calculated standard deviations for variation in the vehicle speed as a function of the pedestrian projection distance; the analysis was taken from the paper by Simms et al.8

sec.title: Pedestrian speed prediction
sec.p: A third Monte Carlo data set (data set 3) was generated (N = 10,000,000) to account for variability in the pedestrian projection distance S with the vehicle speed and Vp/Vc as a function of the ratio H/L of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset of the pedestrian contact with the vehicle (see the regression relations in Appendix 1). The inputs to this simulation were uniformly distributed H/L values and uniformly distributed S values, as detailed in Table 3. Each randomly chosen pedestrian projection distance S was converted to a predicted vehicle speed using the relationship between Vc and S1/2 (see the above section on the relationship between the vehicle speed and the pedestrian projection distance). Similarly, each randomly selected H/L ratio was used in the H/L versus Vp/Vc regressions developed from the CIP simulation to produce a ratio of Vp/Vc (see Appendix 1) at a randomly selected confidence limit. Linear interpolation was used between the confidence limits and deciles. Using this Monte Carlo approach, a distribution of pedestrian speeds was derived.

caption.p: Input parameters for the Monte Carlo pedestrian speed prediction model (data set 3).

sec.p: Simms et al.8 found that the relationship between the square root of the pedestrian projection distance and the car speed was almost linear and Elliott et al.14 found that the relationship between Vp/Vc and H/L was linear; therefore by combining both relationships a linear relationship between Vp/S1/2 and H/L is generated. The regression coefficients were generated by regressing Vp/S1/2 versus H/L in data set 3 at overall, normal and probable confidence limits for the struck-leg-leading case, the struck-leg-lagging case and the overall case where the position in the gait cycle is unknown (see Appendix 2). For clarity, a summary of the three Monte Carlo simulations is given in Table 4.

caption.p: Summary of the Monte Carlo simulations performed.

tr.td: MADYMO Fourier head angle versus gait

sec.title: Approaches for pedestrian speed prediction in accident reconstruction
sec.p: As previously outlined for vehicle speed predictions,8,10,23 speed estimates in pedestrian–vehicle collisions are required for various purposes, including general traffic safety studies, biomechanical injury research and litigation. A degree of uncertainty is inevitable and therefore a confidence interval is more meaningful than a single speed estimate, but the acceptable range of uncertainty depends on the proposed use for the prediction. To cater for the various applications it is proposed that three different confidence levels be considered.

list-item.p: The 50th percentile range between the lower 25th percentile to the upper 25th percentile limits is the ‘probable range’ and broadly corresponds to the legal expression ‘on balance of probabilities’, as there is 50% likelihood that the vehicle speed is bounded by these limits.

The 95th percentile range from the lower 2.5th percentile to the upper 2.5th percentile limits is the ‘normal’ confidence limit and broadly corresponds to the range of collision speeds in the large majority of cases.

The 99.8th percentile range from the lower 0.1st percentile to the upper 0.1st percentile limit is the ‘overall’ confidence limit and may be considered in the context of the legal definition of ‘beyond reasonable doubt’.8,10

Analysis of the Monte Carlo simulation data is used in this paper to present confidence limits based on these three statistical definitions. Further justification for this approach has been given by Simms et al.8

sec.title: Results
MADYMO versus CIP transverse offset predictions
sec.p: A comparison of the MADYMO and CIP model responses for the transverse offset should consider both the mean and the range throughout the gait cycle. Figure 4 shows the mean transverse offset H for the nine cases (three different vehicle speeds at three different pedestrian speeds). There is almost a 1:1 correspondence between the models. A comparison of the range is more complex because of the confounding effects of the vehicle speed and the pedestrian speed. Accordingly, it is more meaningful to compare patterns than absolute amplitudes. To achieve this, the CIP model responses were first scaled (shifted and normalized) so that the minimum value was 0 and the maximum value was 1 for each case of different vehicle and pedestrian speeds. These scaling factors were applied to the corresponding MADYMO responses, and a third-order Fourier curve was then fitted to the scaled MADYMO data. The scaled CIP responses were then compared with the 95% prediction bounds of the Fourier curve fitted to the scaled MADYMO data. Figure 5 shows that the scaled CIP curves largely fall within the 95% prediction bounds presented.

caption.p: Mean CIP versus MADYMO transverse offsets.
Scaled CIP versus scaled MADYMO relative transverse offsets as a function of gait.

sec.title: Application of the CIP model to the relationships between Vp, Vc, H and L
sec.p: Monte Carlo simulations for the CIP model (data set 1) for the struck leg leading and the struck leg lagging produced two distinct clouds, with only a small overlap (Figure 6). Higher H/L values resulted when the struck leg was lagging. The combination of both data sets into an overall data set results in a bimodal distribution (Figures 6 and 7). For this overall case, the most likely pedestrian speed for a given H/L is not clear as there are two distributions combined. The bimodal nature of the distribution can be seen in Figure 7, for H/L = 0.1 (±0.025).

caption.p: Vp/Vc versus H/L for both the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case, with overlap shown for the CIP model (data set 1).
Bimodal distribution of the overall case when H/L = 0.1 (±0.025) for the CIP model (data set 1).

sec.title: Effects of the car shape and the pedestrian size
sec.p: Figure 8 and Figure 9 show H/L versus Vp/Vc for various car shapes and different pedestrian sizes respectively. As can be seen, the variation is minimal, especially when compared with the variation due to the gait (see Figure 6). The variations due to the gait mask the effects of the car shape and the pedestrian anthropometrics.

caption.p: Vp/Vc versus H/L for various car shapes using the CIP model (data set 1).
Vp/Vc versus H/L with pedestrian anthropometric variation using the CIP model (data set 1).

sec.title: Linear regressions of Vp/Vc versus H/L
sec.p: The results of the linear regressions of data set 1, as described in the section on the case when H/L is nominally zero, are displayed in Figure 10. The highly linear relationship between Vp/Vc and H/L can be clearly seen.

caption.p: Linear overall, normal and probable range regressions for Vp/Vc versus H/L for the CIP model (data set 1).

sec.title: Case when H/L is nominally zero
sec.p: The CIP model cases (data set 1) where H/L lay between −0.025 and 0.025 were investigated and a distribution of Vp/Vc for these cases was produced for both the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case. Figure 11 shows these distributions.

caption.p: Distribution of Vp/Vc at H/L = 0 for (a) the struck leg leading, (b) the struck leg lagging and (c) all gaits for the CIP model (data set 1).

sec.title: The head rotation angle θ versus the vehicle speed Vc
sec.p: The distribution of the head angle θ about the coronal plane as a function of Vc for the Fourier MADYMO Monte Carlo simulations (data set 2) is shown in Figure 12 for speeds up to 108 km/h. Figure 13 shows the frequency distributions of θ at 20 km/h, 40 km/h, 60 km/h, 80 km/h and 100 km/h, which demonstrate the prominence of large angles (angles with an absolute value much greater than zero).

caption.p: Distribution of the head rotation angle θ versus the vehicle speed Vc for MADYMO Fourier Monte Carlo simulations (data set 2) showing the high density at large angles (N = 1,000,000).
Distribution of the head rotation angle θ for MADYMO Fourier Monte Carlo simulations (data set 2) for impact speeds of (a) 20 km/h, (b) 40 km/h, (c) 60 km/h, (d) 80 km/h and (e) 100 km/h.

sec.title: Regression equations for predicting the pedestrian speed
sec.p:
Using the pedestrian speed prediction model (data set 3), regression equations of the form

where A and B are regression parameters and t is a normally distributed random variable (the mean is 0, and the standard deviation is 1). It can be seen from the above equations that the standard deviation of Vp/S1/2 versus H/L had a cubic relationship. The corresponding coefficient of variation (COV) (ratio of the standard deviation to the mean) for the resulting pedestrian speed prediction is shown in Figure 14.

caption.p: COV for Vp as a function of H/L for the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case for the pedestrian speed prediction model (data set 3).
COV: coefficient of variation.

sec.title: Comparison with staged tests
sec.p: A comparison of the regression model predictions for Vp/Vc with the CTS staged dummy tests25–30 is given in Table 5. As the dummies did not replicate the human gait, the test results are compared with the overall predictions (see Appendix 1).

caption.p: Comparison of the ratio Vp/Vc for staged dummy tests25–30 and the overall CIP model regression (see Appendix 1).

sec.p: Figure 15 compares the staged test data with the 50th percentile overall prediction and the probable (50%), normal (95%) and overall (99.8%) ranges. The test data has a similar trend to the model prediction with 4 out of 6 within the probable range and all 6 within the normal range. Linear regression analysis of the staged test data yields a regression slope of 1.03 with a standard error of 0.128. This compares to the model the 50th percentile slope of 0.92. Further comparison of the difference between the model prediction (the 50th percentile) and staged test values yields a mean difference of 0.004 with a standard deviation of 0.039. The corresponding t-value is 0.28 (critical t-value at P = 5% is 2.57).

caption.p: Comparison of the Vp/Vc versus H/L relationship for the CTS staged dummy tests with the overall regression model mean and probable and normal ranges (see Appendix 1).
CTS: Crash Test Service.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: There are currently no methods for predicting the pedestrian pre-impact speed following a vehicle–pedestrian collision, despite the influence that the pedestrian speed has on the head impact location on the vehicle12 and its importance during legal proceedings. In this paper a CIP pedestrian model12,14 and analysis of the previously reported MADYMO-derived Fourier curves relating the transverse offset (between the primary and secondary pedestrian contacts with the vehicle) and the location of the head injury (see Figure 2) as a function of the pedestrian gait13 are used together with the well-established relationship between the pedestrian projection distance and the square root of the vehicle impact speed (see, for example, the book by Simms and Wood) to address the problem of pedestrian pre-impact speed prediction.

The CIP model predictions for the longitudinal and transverse offsets between the primary and secondary body contacts with the vehicle have been validated by comparison with damage locations from staged cadaver tests, dummy tests and accident reconstructions,12 but the available test data are limited. In this paper, further comparison between the MADYMO pedestrian model and the CIP model for the transverse offset (see Figure 5) shows that the CIP model curves largely fall within the 95% prediction bounds for the MADYMO model results. It can be concluded that further experimental data are needed but that the CIP model satisfactorily predicts the MADYMO model responses relating to the transverse offset of a pedestrian between the primary and secondary impacts in wrap-trajectory collisions.

A linear relationship between H/L (the ratio of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset of the damage locations on the vehicle) and Vp/Vc (the ratio of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle speed) was previously observed12,14 and is clearly evident again in Figure 10. The basis of this can be understood by consideration of the head as a mass in free flight between the primary and secondary contacts of the pedestrian with the vehicle where the displacement and velocity vectors are similar. In this paper, the CIP model is used to show that the relationship between Vp/Vc and H/L has different distributions for the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case (see Figures 6 and 7). Also, the influences of the vehicle shape and the pedestrian size are shown to be small (see Figures 8 and 9). The vehicle shape was shown to have almost no influence (Figure 8), and it is expected that this is because the variation in the bumper height is small for vehicles in popular use, particularly when compared with the variations due to the gait. The pedestrian size was shown to have a small effect, but both variances are much smaller than the effects of the gait.

Using the linear relationship between the ratio Vp/Vc of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle speed and the ratio H/L of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset, the pedestrian speed can be estimated, given that H/L can be measured from vehicle damage patterns and that the vehicle speed can sometimes be determined from the pedestrian projection distance8–11 or the wrap-around distance.23 However, the transverse offset and the amount of head rotation about the coronal plane (see Figure 2) between the primary and secondary pedestrian contacts with the vehicle vary with the pedestrian gait in a cyclical manner, which has been previously modelled using third-order Fourier curves.13 Monte Carlo simulation based on this modelling yields the distribution of head rotations θ as a function of Vc from data set 2 (see Figure 12), which shows that the density of head rotation angles is highest towards the positive and negative extremities of θ angles. The histogram plots in Figure 13 at 20 km/h, 40 km/h, 60 km/h, 80 km/h and 100 km/h (derived from the data in Figure 12) show more clearly that head rotations are generally either significantly greater than or less than zero but that head rotations close to 0° are uncommon. It is thus generally possible to distinguish between anterior and posterior head injury locations relative to the coronal plane as the head will usually rotate through large angles. Since it has recently been shown that anterior contact locations on the head are associated with the struck leg lagging and that posterior contact locations on the head are associated with the struck leg leading,13 it is generally possible to estimate the position in the gait cycle based on the location of the injury to the pedestrian’s head (anterior or posterior). This approach reduces the uncertainty in the resulting pedestrian speed prediction. Lissajous plots of the Fourier relationships (presented by Elliott et al.13) between the changes in the head rotation and in the transverse offset with the gait (Figure 16) show that, for vehicle speeds ranging from 18 km/h to 108 km/h, the struck-leg-leading cases (15–70% of the gait cycle18) produce mostly negative rotations (posterior head injury locations), and the struck-leg-lagging cases produce mostly positive rotations (anterior head injury locations). These plots also show the manner in which the head rotations tend to dwell at the extremities of the cycle. Accordingly, the use of head injury location to predict whether the struck leg was leading or lagging is applicable over a broad vehicle speed range.

caption.p: Lissajous plots for (a) a low speed (Vc = 18 km/h),(b) a medium speed (Vc = 63 km/h) and (c) a high speed (Vc = 108 km/h), showing the variation in the transverse offset versus the head rotation with the gait and showing the influence of the gait on the anterior or posterior head injury (adapted from the paper by Elliott et al.13).

sec.p: Despite frequent interpretation to the contrary, a transverse offset of nominally zero does not imply a pedestrian speed of zero (stationary pedestrian). Figure 11 shows the distribution of Vp/Vc values when H/L is nominally zero (±0.025) for the struck-leg-leading case, for the struck-leg-lagging case and for the general case (gait position unknown). Considering the general cases (Figure 11(c)), 85% of those are for the struck leg leading, and so a struck-leg-leading configuration is more than five times more likely than a struck-leg-lagging configuration. Again for the general case (Figure 11(c)), 69% of cases lie in the Vp/Vc range 0.04–0.1, so that the probability that a Vp/Vc ratio in an individual case is in this range is more than 2:1.

For the case of the struck leg leading, the most probable ratio of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle speed is about 0.07 (see Figure 11(a)). Table 6 outlines the resulting most probable pedestrian speeds Vp as well as the 69% likelihood range (see above) for a range of vehicle speeds with a transverse offset of nominally zero and with the struck leg leading. At a vehicle speed of 60 km/h, it is most probable that the pedestrian was walking across the road (Vp = 4.2 km/h) while, at a speed of 100 km/h, it is most probable that the pedestrian was jogging (Vp = 7 km/h), clearly indicating that the pedestrian was not stationary. It can be concluded that an H/L ratio of almost zero indicates that, on the balance of probabilities, the pedestrian was most probably moving at the instant of impact.

caption.p: Most probable pedestrian speeds when H/L is nominally zero for the struck-leg-leading cases for the CIP model (data set 1).

sec.p: Knowledge of the pedestrian’s stance reduces the pedestrian speed range. Two distinct regions in the relation between H/L and Vp/Vc are evident in Figure 6, highlighting the influence of the position of the struck leg (leading or lagging). Each of these two data sets is normally distributed, but Figure 7 shows that the overall data set (when the pedestrian stance is unknown) is bimodal.

For example, consider a case where an H/L value of 0.15 was recorded from the damage on the vehicle and the vehicle speed was estimated to be 80 km/h from the pedestrian projection distance. If the pedestrian gait (struck leg leading or lagging) is not known, the model predicts that the absolute pedestrian speed range was somewhere between approximately 5.4 km/h and 22 km/h (see Figure 6), which is a wide range. If the position in the gait cycle is known, the absolute range becomes 5.4–14.4 km/h for the struck-leg-lagging case and 10.8–21.6 km/h for the struck-leg-leading case. Thus, knowledge of the gait cycle is important as it reduces uncertainty. Such knowledge also allows prediction of a most probable (50th percentile) speed, which is not possible for the overall case owing to the bimodal distribution.

Given the linear relations between H/L and Vp/Vc (see the section on application of the CIP model to the relationships between Vp, Vc, H and L and Appendix 1), provided that a pedestrian projection distance is known (vehicle speed), a pedestrian speed can be calculated. It has previously been shown8–11 that in general the square root of pedestrian projection distance is approximately proportional to the vehicle speed.7 Incorporating this relationship with the linear relation between H/L and Vp/Vc, the pedestrian speed is obtained using regression equations of the form

where A and B incorporate the uncertainty in the relation between Vp and H/L. This regression was performed for probable, overall and normal confidence limits (see the section on the approaches for pedestrian speed prediction in accident reconstruction) for the struck-leg-leading, struck-leg-lagging and overall cases. However, the data set for the overall case is bimodal, meaning that the average of the probable lower and probable upper confidence limits is not the most likely value for the pedestrian speed (see Figure 7). The equations in Table 12 in Appendix 2 should therefore be used with caution for the general case where the gait cycle position is unknown.

Using a cubic regression of the standard deviation of Vp/S1/2 versus H/L, a relationship between the pedestrian speed, the H/L ratio and the projection distance S that is applicable at any confidence level (set by choosing the appropriate t value) was developed for both the struck-leg-leading case (equation (1)) and the struck-leg-lagging case (equation (2)). The COVs (see Figure 14) are significantly higher at lower H/L ratios but rapidly decrease for higher H/L ratios. Since the absolute speeds of pedestrians are low, the range of likely pedestrian speed predictions remains modest despite the high values of the COV. For example, for the struck-leg-leading case and a measured H/L ratio of 0.1, the COV is about 0.19. If the mean pedestrian speed obtained was 5 km/h (1.4 m/s), the resulting plus or minus one standard deviation prediction range (probability of 2:1) would be approximately 4–6 km/h (1.1–1.7 m/s). For the struck-leg-lagging case, if the mean pedestrian speed obtained was again 5 km/h (1.4 m/s), the prediction bound would be approximately 3.5–6.5 km/h (1.0–1.8 m/s). Both of these ranges are relatively tight prediction bounds.

Comparison of the predicted Vp/Vc values from the 50th percentile overall data (gait unknown) with staged dummy tests25–30 shows that there is no clear pattern of over-prediction or under-prediction (see Table 5). Figure 15 shows the test data to be within or on the probable range in five out of six cases and within the normal range in all cases. Linear regression analysis of Vp/Vc versus H/L for the staged test data yields a regression slope of 0.86 with a standard error of 0.105. This compares with the model 50th percentile slope of 0.92. Further comparison of the difference between the model prediction (50th percentile) and the staged test values yields a mean difference of 0.036 with a standard deviation of 0.054. The corresponding t value is 1.64 (P = 16%) which is not statistically significant at the 5% level (t = 1.64 compared with t = 2.57 for P = 0.05).

Some limitations should be noted as the model presented here was based on no vehicle braking. When vehicle braking is accompanied by dive, this can have a significant influence on H/L and will be the focus of future investigations. Furthermore, since the measurable damage locations on the vehicle may be at the bonnet leading-edge rather than the bumper, the use of this damage to obtain an estimate for the primary contact location (and hence the longitudinal (L) and transverse (H) offsets) needs to be assessed. For a modern passenger car striking an adult pedestrian at 40km/h, the bonnet leading-edge contact occurs around 20 ms after the bumper contact.7 For a pedestrian speed of 1 m/s, the whole body transverse distance travelled in that time is about 2 cm, but friction effects would reduce that motion considerably for the struck leg, which is effectively pinned to the car at the contact location. In this paper, it is assumed that the difference between the transverse offset measured from the bumper compared to the bonnet leading-edge is negligible, and the comparison with the available moving dummy tests25–30 (see Figure 15) indicates no mean bias, supporting this assumption. The effects of gait on the measurement of H would be zero on average, but could lead to an increase in uncertainty. Future experiments with moving dummies with realistic gait may help to elucidate this. The measurement of the longitudinal offset (L) can be taken to a point on the bumper directly ahead of the bonnet leading-edge damage with expected negligible difference with the actual offset.

The transverse offset H is also influenced by the time lapse between the initial impact at the front of the car and the head impact, while the longitudinal offset L is influenced by both the time between the first and second impacts and the geometry of the front of the vehicle at impact (dive or no dive). The influence of the vehicle front geometry (dive or no dive) on the longitudinal damage offset L has been reported elsewhere.21,23 In the presence of vehicle dive, the longitudinal distance L is increased primarily owing to the changed vehicle front geometry. For braking without dive the only factor influencing the longitudinal distance L is the change in the car speed as a result of braking during the time lapse between the front and head impacts. This has been shown to be negligible for vehicle speeds above 40 km/h. On this basis, the data presented in this paper can be applied for the two cases of no vehicle braking and vehicle braking without dive (initial stages of braking) for collision speeds above 40 km/h. The distribution of vehicle braking and vehicle dive was interpreted from a review of accidents between 2002 and 200931 and accidents reported by Wood et al.23 These reports showed that the distribution of pedestrian accidents is as follows: no braking, 43%; braking without dive, 33%; braking with dive, 24%. On this basis, the model would be applicable in about 76% of cases.

The model was applied to passenger cars, but not to high-fronted vehicles such as light trucks and vans where forward-projection-type impacts are more common. Accordingly, the model should only be applied in cases where wrap projection has occurred.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Experimental data for the relationship between the pedestrian transverse offset between the primary and secondary damage locations on the vehicle and the pedestrian speed are limited. However, a CIP momentum-based pedestrian model yields similar predictions to MADYMO for the transverse offset between the primary and secondary damage locations on a vehicle following a vehicle–pedestrian collision. Using the CIP model, Monte Carlo simulation of a side-struck pedestrian demonstrated linear relations between the ratio of the transverse offset H to the longitudinal offset L of the damage locations on the vehicle and the ratio of the pedestrian velocity Vp to the vehicle velocity Vc over a range of passenger car types and pedestrian anthropometrics. These relationships compare favourably with tose from staged dummy tests and, when used together with measured values for the transverse and longitudinal offset distances and an estimate for the vehicle speed from the pedestrian projection distance, the pedestrian pre-impact speed can be estimated.

Analysis showed that a nominally zero transverse offset indicates that the pedestrian was probably in motion at the instant of impact, especially for cases where the struck leg of the pedestrian was leading.

Separate analysis of the relations between the pedestrian head rotation about the longitudinal axis and the transverse offset of the primary and secondary damage patterns based on modelling with MADYMO showed that it is generally possible to distinguish between anterior and posterior head injury locations (relative to the coronal plane) for a side-struck pedestrian and that these can be related to the struck-leg-back (struck-leg-lagging) and struck-leg-forward (struck-leg-leading) portions of the gait cycle respectively. This ability to infer the pre-impact gait position of the pedestrian from the head injury location reduces the uncertainty in the pedestrian speed prediction considerably. Therefore, separate reconstruction relationships between the pedestrian speed and the horizontal and transverse offset distances on the vehicle are given for the struck-leg-lagging and the struck-leg-leading cases, as well as an overall relationship where the leg position is unknown.

Regression equations with confidence limits are presented for predicting the pedestrian pre-impact speed using only H/L and the pedestrian projection distance. These provide the first means to predict the pedestrian speed from limited post-accident damage locations on the vehicle and the pedestrian projection distance.

app.title: Appendix 1
app.p: In this appendix the coefficients of the regression equation relating the ratio Vp/Vc of the pedestrian speed to the vehicle pre-impact speed to the ratio H/L of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset of the primary and secondary impact locations of the side-facing pedestrian on the vehicle are given in Tables 7 to 9, where the equation is in the form

caption.p: Overall case.
Struck-leg-leading case.
Struck-leg-lagging case.

app.title: Appendix 2
app.p: Coefficients for the regression equations relating the pedestrian pre-impact speed Vp to the ratio H/L of the transverse offset to the longitudinal offset of the primary and secondary impact locations of the side-facing pedestrian on the vehicle and the pedestrian projection distance for wrap-trajectory vehicle–pedestrian impacts are given in Tables 10 to 12. The overall case is a combination of the struck-leg-leading case and the struck-leg-lagging case. As a result, the distribution within this data set is bimodal, composed of both the struck-leg-leading data set and the struck-leg-lagging data set (Figure 6). The consequence of this is that the average of the probable lower and probable upper confidence limits is not the most likely value for the pedestrian speed. The equation
employed in Tables 10 to 12 should therefore be used with caution, keeping in mind the bimodal nature of the distribution.

caption.p: Struck-leg-leading case.
Struck-leg-lagging case.
Overall case.
